channel.title: LW Jekyll/GitHub Pages Sandbox
channel.description: This is a sandbox test site for Lee Worden's experiments with Jekyll and GitHub Pages

item.title: Ebola Data
item.description:
[This is a Working Markup adaptation of a WorkingWiki page that downloads and plots recent data on Ebola cases.]

The data file

UNIQ-WW-1411661745-QINU is downloaded from HDX.

wget by default keeps the timestamp from the download server. This will be useful in some cases, but right now we don’t want it, because HDX changes the location for each new update, and we are tracking manually. So for now, we are using “touch” when we download, and the project will automatically update after you manually change the file location.

UNIQ-WW-23253309-QINU

Exploration

UNIQ-WW-1386583188-QINU

UNIQ-WW-296728375-QINU

UNIQ-WW-671185309-QINU

UNIQ-WW-1497345580-QINU

UNIQ-WW-1553095413-QINU

UNIQ-WW-574780956-QINU

UNIQ-WW-1908967395-QINU

Helper code

UNIQ-WW-1679490483-QINU

item.title: Simple R Demo
item.description:
[This demo blog post accompanies a post on leeworden.net: Working Markup: makefile-driven literate programming for reproducible web publishing. Scroll down to see the source text for this post.]

Announcing Working Markup, a text-processing tool that supports reproducible research by providing a streamlined way to develop and document the various computations you do in your research as steps embedded in web pages and blog posts, written in arbitrary markup languages.

For example, you can embed some R code in your markup source by inserting a “source-file” tag:

<source-file filename="demo.R">
print( 5 * 7 );
curve( x * exp(-x), 0, 5 );
</source-file>

UNIQ-WW-1234395074-QINU

And then run the code and display the output by inserting “project-file” tags:

<project-file filename="demo.Rout"/>

<project-file filename="demo.Rout.png"/>

Those project-file tags come out looking like this:

UNIQ-WW-983322058-QINU

UNIQ-WW-1274320633-QINU

Reproducibility

  • Click through to see the source text of this post

item.title: Sage Dynamics Demo
item.description:
Intro

[This is an adaptation of a page from my open lab notebook wiki, as a demo of our Working Markup reproducible web-publishing system. Scroll down to the final section for info on how this post is made, including source code. -lw]

This post demonstrates a set of Sage classes I wrote to work with continuous-time dynamical systems, the kind of system my colleagues and I use a lot as mathematical models.

The computations in this blog post are implemented in two parts. The Sage class library is kept in a GitHub repository by itself, and the Sage scripts that use the library to implement a simple demo system on this page are stored as part of this page.

On this page I use those Sage classes to construct a simple population biology model of two populations, and analyze and evaluate it.

The Sage code for this model is below. Here’s its output, in LaTeX format:

UNIQ-WW-2023198534-QINU

Here’s the state space plot that the program creates, showing a representative trajectory of the model’s dynamics, with flow vector field and zero-net-growth isoclines:

UNIQ-WW-1935564090-QINU

And a bifurcation diagram of total population vs. UNIQ-WW-873343858-QINU (black=stable, red=repelling point, blue=saddle):

UNIQ-WW-750105041-QINU

Source code

Here is the source code for this page’s demo:

UNIQ-WW-2145130711-QINU

And a small makefile to get the above Sage code to connect with the libraries pulled from GitHub into a separate directory: UNIQ-WW-126941183-QINU

Reproducibility

Here are instructions to run this Sage code yourself. You will need Sage, GNU make, git, perl, and maybe some other utilities installed.

  • Download and unpack the source code from this page: UNIQ-WW-1826417759-QINU
  • Clone the Sage library code from Git: https://github.com/worden-lee/SageDynamics
  • In the code directory from this page, edit the makefile libraries.mk so that it has the correct locations for the SageUtils and SageDynamics directories that you checked out from Git.
  • In the code directory, run make ode-system-demo.sage.out.tex

To see how this blog post is written, with source code embedded, see https://github.com/worden-lee/github-pages-sandbox/blob/master/_posts/2014-10-20-SageDynamics.markdown.wmd.

item.title: Nomogram
item.description:
Intro

[This is a page from Jonathan Dushoff’s math wiki, adapted for use as a test of my Working Markup blog-post system. Scroll down for info about how this post is made, including source code. -lw]

On this page, I use the free software environment R to construct a nomogram that I read about in a recreational math book when I was a kid. This nomogram solves quadratic equations.

Nomogram

You can print out UNIQ-WW-251818622-QINU, and use a ruler to read off the solutions to the quadratic equation, where the line from UNIQ-WW-1959282585-QINU to UNIQ-WW-1902393481-QINU intersects the scale.

UNIQ-WW-1140804496-QINU

The example above shows the solutions to the equation UNIQ-WW-498295741-QINU. The dashed line connecting UNIQ-WW-1404057582-QINU to UNIQ-WW-336267023-QINU shows the positive solution (4.2), and the dotted line connecting UNIQ-WW-2014415327-QINU to UNIQ-WW-1863926687-QINU shows the negative solution (-1.2).

UNIQ-WW-1653069291-QINU

In this example (UNIQ-WW-168755276-QINU), both solutions are positive (0.2 and 4.8), thus only the dashed line intersects the scale.

Math

We want to draw lines from UNIQ-WW-1533945609-QINU to UNIQ-WW-1958265301-QINU that will pass through a point labeled with UNIQ-WW-1610947634-QINU, where UNIQ-WW-85294990-QINU is a root, satisfying UNIQ-WW-1523487311-QINU. The equation for our line is UNIQ-WW-877723358-QINU. Solve the quadratic to obtain UNIQ-WW-1222250902-QINU, and substitute into the line equation to get UNIQ-WW-857654375-QINU.

If we want all lines corresponding to UNIQ-WW-539452393-QINU to go through our point, we must find one independent of UNIQ-WW-1431024765-QINU. We do this by setting UNIQ-WW-165221135-QINU, to yield UNIQ-WW-105222743-QINU.

Code

Define and call a nomogram function.

UNIQ-WW-1536487850-QINU

Use make to make the example code below depend on the R environment from above (using our custom R rules).

UNIQ-WW-750675945-QINU

Make a nomogram, then define and make example lines.

UNIQ-WW-708823983-QINU

Here’s another example.

UNIQ-WW-1940005233-QINU

UNIQ-WW-945449287-QINU

Printable

UNIQ-WW-1841082951-QINU

UNIQ-WW-1332893874-QINU

Export source code

This project is designed for reproducible research.

  • This entire website (including the source text of this blog post, with all the source code included) is available for cloning at https://github.com/worden-lee/github-pages-sandbox. I’m planning to write instructions for processing it soon.
  • To reproduce the full blog post you’ll need to have the following installed: Jekyll, git, R, latexml, GNU make, perl (and maybe other things - bug reports welcome).
  • Here is an automatically-generated tar file of the source file contents: UNIQ-WW-2110949773-QINU. You should be able to unpack this directory and simply run ‘make example.Rout.png’ to build the first image above, and similar commands to build the other output files.
  • To reproduce these outputs you will need GNU make, perl, and R installed.

To see the source text of this blog post, with the R and makefile code embedded, see https://github.com/worden-lee/github-pages-sandbox/blob/master/_posts/2014-10-15-nomogram.md.wmd.

See also a discussion of how this is put together at http://leeworden.net/lw/node/148 and http://leeworden.net/lw/node/149.

item.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
item.description:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve --watch, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

def print_hi(name)
  puts "Hi, #{name}"
end
print_hi('Tom')
#=> prints 'Hi, Tom' to STDOUT.

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll’s dedicated Help repository.
